data.title: Artifact tool not running on older Linux systems (libstdc++ too old)
data.body:
# Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: UniversalPackages

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises? Azure Pipelines
    
https://dev.azure.com/WRF-CMake/WRF/_build/results?buildId=370&view=logs&jobId=f7ff90bd-af87-5777-db58-ce71fb90295c&taskId=adf83973-db35-58dc-a374-730505a4a34d&lineStart=14&lineEnd=25&colStart=1&colEnd=1


- Agent - Hosted or Private:  Hosted 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: ubuntu 16.04


## Issue Description

I'm running a Container Job on a CentOS 6 image. It looks like the native artifact tool is built on a fairly recent system, meaning that certain Docker images can't execute it because they don't have  a certain minimum libstdc++ version. The [docs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/process/container-phases?view=azure-devops&tabs=yaml#linux-based-containers) are silent about any version requirements and simply ask for glibc-based images, which CentOS is.

Being able to test software on older (still officially supported) Linux versions is important, so I consider this a bug. It can be fixed by re-building the artifact tool on an older Linux system to achieve widest compatibility.

(Also reported by another user for RHEL 6 in [Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/564745/universal-packages-task-failed-because-of-library.html))

data.title: architecture as an input for UseDotNet and DotNetCoreInstaller task
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreInstallerV0, DotNetCoreInstallerV1, UseDotNetV2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    
dnceng Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
Private agent, agent 2.150.3, Ubuntu 16.04 ARM64

## Issue Description

get_machine_architecture contains the following:

https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/08914a70defbdbe73b2bb87e8d0663bdbeb248e0/Tasks/UseDotNetV2/externals/get-os-distro.sh#L159-L178

This is... fundamentally not how `uname` should be used.

1. `uname` refers to the profile of the running kernel, not the executing environment. It can be a 100% mismatch, and that's valid and fine. The .NET Core environment which gets installed needs to match the executing environment, not the kernel.

Some examples:

```
(xenial-armhf)root@xam-softiron-16:/# uname -a
Linux xam-softiron-16 4.15.0-50-generic #54~16.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Wed May 8 15:55:41 UTC 2019 aarch64 aarch64 aarch64 GNU/Linux
(xenial-armhf)root@xam-softiron-16:/# file /bin/bash
/bin/bash: ELF 32-bit LSB executable, ARM, EABI5 version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, interpreter /lib, for GNU/Linux 3.2.0, BuildID[sha1]=9a214a5bbfe98a862fd835fdcbfa1d9f8dabff0e, stripped
```

```
root@breakfast:/# uname -a
Linux breakfast 4.15.0-50-generic #54-Ubuntu SMP Mon May 6 18:46:08 UTC 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
root@breakfast:/# file /bin/bash 
/bin/bash: ELF 32-bit LSB shared object, Intel 80386, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, interpreter /lib, for GNU/Linux 3.2.0, BuildID[sha1]=d3d60e9d8193746d270cd74bcb2f5742ffc65d48, stripped
```

In both these cases, these are 64-bit kernels with 32-bit executing environments. There is no guarantee that 64-bit libraries are available to execute 64-bit code, and it is a 32-bit .NET Core which should be installed.

2. `armv7l` is not the only valid `uname` which requires a 32-bit .NET Core. 32-bit compatibility kernel profile on 64-bit ARM kernels will show `armv8l`:

```
$ uname -a
Linux xam-softiron-15 4.15.0-50-generic #54~16.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Wed May 8 15:55:41 UTC 2019 armv8l armv8l armv8l GNU/Linux
```

### Task logs

```
##[section]Starting: Install .NET Core 3.0 preview
==============================================================================
Task         : .NET Core SDK/Runtime Installer
Description  : Acquires a version of the .NET Core SDK/Runtime from the internet or the local cache and adds it to the PATH. Use this task to change the version of .NET Core used in subsequent tasks.

==============================================================================

Found version 3.0.100-preview5-011568 in channel 3.0 for user specified version spec: 3.0.100-preview5-011568
Version 3.0.100-preview5-011568 was not found in cache.

[command]/home/builder/azdo32/_work/_tasks/DotNetCoreInstaller_b0ce7256-7898-45d3-9cb5-176b752bfea6/1.0.1/externals/get-os-distro.sh

data.title: NpmAuthenticate should handle paths better
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: NpmAuthenticate  

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

The `NpmAuthenticate` task includes an argument `workingFile`. It would be helpful if one could use (environment) variables in this path. Also `~` is not supported.

This snippet:
```yml
      - task: npmAuthenticate@0
        inputs:
          workingFile: ~/.npmrc
```

results in "The .npmrc file you selected at /home/vsts/work/1/s/~/.npmrc does not currently exist.", whereas I would expect the task to look for just `~/.npmrc`.
Trying to use `workingFile: $HOME/.npmrc` instead, yields `/home/vsts/work/1/s/$HOME/.npmrc`, where I would expect `$HOME/.npmrc`

https://github.com/microsoft/IIS.Compression/tree/master/.pipelines

We would like to index the sources and submit symbols to the internal symbol server so that support engineers can easily debug these components in source-mode through windbg for the customers. 

Is there any plan to support GitHub source provider in this build task?
If not, what would be the alternative workaround to achieve the same thing through Azure pipeline?

Thanks,
Yanbing Shi

## Required Information

## Environment

- dotnet-reportgenerator-cli  Version="4.1.5" 

## Issue description
I am configuring azure CI pipeline. And I've added following steps:

- test
- report generator
- publish code coverage

ReportGenerator is the well know tool https://github.com/danielpalme/ReportGenerator
that exists in the Azure Devops marketplace 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15476934/57530133-e17cee00-7336-11e9-94ae-5139c511e7b6.png)

in the ReportGenerator I apply filters to exclude test projects from the total test coverage report and exclude extra xUnit assemblies from analysis. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15476934/57530350-56e8be80-7337-11e9-8341-296078da5111.png)

In the console log I see that following filters were applied: 

 -assemblyfilters:-[*.tests]* -[*.Tests]* -[xunit.]* -[*.Test]* -[Xunit.]*
 -classfilters:-[*.tests]* -[*.Tests]* -[xunit.]* -[*.Test]* -[Xunit.]*
 -filefilters:-[*.tests]* -[*.Tests]* -[xunit.]* -[*.Test]* -[Xunit.]*

as you also can see, on the next step Publishing code coverage task starts and it re-generates summary report one more time without applying the assembly filtering.
it became like this after integration with reportGenerator tool 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/release-notes/2019/sprint-150-update#cobertura-code-coverage-report-updates

data.title: Merge coverage reports from multiple runs
data.body:
## Required Information

*Type*: bug
**Enter Task Name**: PublishCodeCoverageResults@1  

## Environment

- Server - Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description

Task PublishCodeCoverageResults@1 supports reports from multiple files, but the summary just shows the first match. 

### Task logs

The behavior for a task configured with a wildcard path for the coverage file is a little inconsistent:

```
      - task: PublishCodeCoverageResults@1
        inputs:
          codeCoverageTool: cobertura
          summaryFileLocation: $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/packages/*/build/coverage/coverage.cobertura.xml
```

In this example, there are few coverage.cobertura.xml files from separate test runs. Unfortunately, I receive warning:

```
##[warning]Multiple file or directory matches were found. Using the first match: ```

Ideally, the summary would show the coverage for each assembly separately. Because I'm working in a monorepo and would like to trace multiple folders separately.

A similar issue has been reported in https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/vsts-docs/issues/4135

data.title: Support more protocols with IIS Web Application Management
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question, Feature

**Enter Task Name**: IISWebAppManagementOnMachineGroupV0 (IIS Web Application Management)

## Environment
Both TFS and Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description
For handling all scenarios supported by IIS the pipeline task should also support managing bindings for protocols like net.tcp, net.msmq and so on.
I had a short look on the implementation of the source code and think it should be possible to implement without much effort.
Unfortunately I cannot bypass the problem by using the "Additional appcmd.exe commands" since I cannot check whether the binding for a particular protocol, host, port does already exist or not and therefore commands like `set site /site.name "$(Webserver.WebsiteName)" -+bindings.[protocol='net.tcp',bindingInformation='808:*']` fail.

I probably try to implement it and send a PR but first want to gather some feedback on the idea in general.

data.title: Updated XCode task - teamId does not require signingOption auto anymore
data.body: Fixing #10312

data.title: XCode@5 only passes teamId when signingOption = auto
data.body:
**Problem:**
Currently, XCode@5 task only passes teamId parameter only when signingOption is set to `auto`. This is incorrect and does not cover all use cases.

**Example use case:**
xcode project is generated (i.e. by Unity3d) and does have provisioning profile / teamId set. Provisioning profile can be set by doing "manual" signing. However passing provisioning profile without teamId would result in the following error:

_error: Signing for "Unity-iPhone" requires a development team. Select a development team in the build settings editor that matches the selected profile "iPhone Distribution Ad Hoc". (in target 'Unity-iPhone')_

**Resolution:**
Allow to pass teamId with any signingOption.

data.title: [App Center Test Task, Xamarin.UITest] Auto-Detect Test Tools Directory
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: 
[AppCenterTestV1](https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AppCenterTestV1)

## Issue Description

For Xamarin.UITest, the current App Center Test task, requires the `Test tools directory` as an input.

But because this directory uses the [Xamarin.UITest NuGet Package](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Xamarin.UITest/) version number, the task will fail each time the developer updates the version of the NuGet package. For example, the directory for Xamarin.UITest v2.2.7 would be `$(UserProfile)\.nuget\packages\xamarin.uitest\2.2.7\tools\test-cloud.exe`.

The Xamarin.UITest version can be auto-detected using the name of the UITest csproj file and the name of its dll output. 

Here's an example of how to auto-detect the directories using a bash script.

```bash
UITestProjectPath=`find "$(Build.Repository.LocalPath)" -name $UITestCSProj`
echo UITestProjectPath: $UITestProjectPath

UITestDLLPath=`find "$(Build.Repository.LocalPath)" -name "$UITestDLLName" | grep bin`
echo UITestDLLPath: $UITestDLLPath

UITestBuildDir=`dirname $UITestDLLPath`
echo UITestBuildDir: $UITestBuildDir

UITestVersionNumber=`grep '[0-9]' $UITestProjectPath | grep Xamarin.UITest|grep -o '[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}'`
echo UITestVersionNumber: $UITestVersionNumber

TestCloudExePath=`find "$(UserProfile)\.nuget\packages" | grep test-cloud.exe | grep $UITestVersionNumber | head -1`
echo TestCloudExe: $TestCloudExe

TestCloudExeDirectory=`dirname $TestCloudExePath`
echo TestCloudExeDirectory: $TestCloudExeDirectory
```

And now, ` --build-dir $UITestBuildDir` and `--uitest-tools-dir $TestCloudExeDirectory` can be used to submit the app to App Center Test.

The big benefit here is that the name of the `csproj` and its dll output rarely change and this task will no longer fail when the developers update the Xamarin.UITest NuGet Package version.

Here is an example of the bash script I am using for my app:
https://github.com/brminnick/AsyncAwaitBestPractices/blob/master/Src/SubmitApkToAppCenterTest.sh

data.title: [SF update manifest task] It should be possible to choose a branch while comparing version against previous build
data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo 

For a list:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
Feature

**Enter Task Name**: Service fabric update manifest task

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    
Both


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
Both

## Issue Description

Update manifest task compares current package files against package for last successful build. But a build can be triggered for more than one branch and hence in such cases, we might be comparing against a build with a different baseline.
It would be better to add support for specifying branch to detect previous build. More details in this [thread](https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/7549#issuecomment-440150544)

data.title: Xcode tests fail when running in parallel
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: Xcode@5  

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description

Hosted agent does not support running tests in Parallel. When tests are set to run in parallel execution the simulators exit early with exit code 65. If this occurs the JUnit results are not generated either, making it hard to diagnose if the issue is part of the project or the hosted agents job.

Running the same build with parallel execution off will succeed.

data.title: "dotnet tool install/update" not working with Azure Artifacts
data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo 

For a list:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question or Feature request

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCLI@2

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Private: Windows Server

## Issue Description

`dotnet tool install` (invoked as custom command via `DotNetCLI@2`) cannot install tool when NuGet points to Azure Artifacts.

We've got an Azure Artifacts feed for our packages that is configured to use the NuGet gallery as upstream source. We've created a `NuGet.config` file pointing to the Azure Artifacts feed only. Restoring packages using the `restore` command works, however trying to restore a tool via a custom command does not. Trying to retrieve information about the package results in a 401 (Unauthorized).

Looking at the implementation of `DotNetCLI@2` it looks like there are special cases for `dotnet pack`, `dotnet push` and `dotnet restore` among other things handling implicit authentication. However there is not special treatment for `dotnet tool install` or `dotnet tool update`.

Feature Request: Handle `dotnet tool install` and `dotnet tool update` or make the authentication globally available to all dotnet commands.

Question: Is there a workaround for this scenario (other than not removing nuget.org via NuGet.config, which would be against the point of using Azure Artifacts with upsteram nuget.org)?

data.title: Question: How do pipelines work?
data.body:
What is it that I have to do to make this magic work?


**My frustration**

I've built so many "build servers" in the last few months I've gotten to the point that I have now given up doing it and I'm starting to try the hosted build services.

Despite my code building, running and deployable from VS locally apparently this is impossible to do via Azure DevOps either by asking the Azure Portal to configure the build pipeline or by asking VS to do it by pointing it at the destination app needing deploying

I've repeatedly deleted and re-created the builds and for some reason nothing appears to work.

The exceptions raised by the build process appear to be different every time I go though the motions of configuring a new pipeline os giving you guys specifics (like logs / exception details) might not help.


**Here's what I'm doing** 

1) Compile my solution locally, run all apps in the solution, confirm they all work.
2) Split main solution out in to .Net / .Net Core solutions as in the past these needed separate build pipelines.
3) Open the split solutions with only 1 app and all dependencies in it, confirm everything still builds and runs.
4) Right click on project > Publish
5) follow wizard to configure deployment info
6) test settings by doing a deploy from VS
7) Under "Continuous Delivery" click "configure" causing VS to tell Azure DevOps to configure the pipeline.
8) ensure everything is checked in, manually trigger the generated build.
9) watch it fail (again)


**Details of my codebase**

To clarify ...
I have 3 applications in my entire setup here.
 - 1 .Net Web API + Odata app
 - 1 .Net Core app ( about 200 lines of code total that just serves up data from http calls to the first app.
 - 1 Azure Functions App consisting of 2 "Simple" Azure functions.

I would expect that these things need different task types to deploy but it seems that generated builds seem to be the same every time looking something like ...

 - Get sources
 - NuGet restore
 - Build Solution (VS Build)
 - Test Assemblies (VS test)
 - Publish Symbols
 - Publish Artifact

... Historically for .Net Core apps we needed different activity types, but this doesn't appear to work for my .Net app either.

... following that, under releases it generates a release with one activity ... "Deploy Azure App Service" which from what I can tell is configured correctly but at the moment isn't getting hit due to build failures.


**Other observations / minor changes**

As i'm using VS 2019 locally I have been changing the pipeline's queue to use the VS2019 one in the cloud instead of the default VS 2017 one, but neither work.
I also tried changing the path to the solution to match only the solution that contained only the configured app to avoid any further "mess" by other project types / compiles that aren't related to what i'm trying to build but that didn't help either.

data.title: PublishBuildArtifacts fails when artifact is open with FileShare.ReadWrite
data.body:
## Required Information

The PublishBuildArtifacts task will fail to upload an artifact when another process has it open with `FileShare.ReadWrite`. This permission allows for other processes to read the file but only if they also have at least `FileShare.Read`. It appears that PublishBuildArtifacts is not doing this and looking for exclusive access to the file. 

As best we can tell from digging through the source the attempted read of the files occur here: 

https://github.com/Microsoft/vso-agent/blob/22d20773eed201eb27dd0f68736ab90846d9ef86/src/agent/filecontainerhelper.ts#L127

Been unable to track down the implementation of that code but guessing it's not using `FileShare.Read`.

**Bug**: this blocks upload of files which are readabel
**Task Name**: PublishBuildArtifacts

## Environment
The environment is Azure Pipelines. Here is an example of a build where this failure occurs. 

https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=2546220

Note: this will require MSFT permissions to view.

data.title: 7z security issue: unpacking RARs (CVE-2018-10115)
data.body:
The ArchiveFiles task depends on 7zip 16.00. Per [CVE-2018-10115](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2018-10115), versions below 18.05 suffer from an RCE bug when unpacking specially-crafted RAR files. While the task itself doesn't unpack RARs (so we're protected in practice), we should upgrade when it's convenient.

Hat tip to [Karl Sanford](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/250597/7zip-vulnerability-and-hosted-build-system.html) for originally reporting this.

data.title: Feature Request: Azure Container Instance (ACI) Task
data.body:
# Feature Request: ACI Support and Azure DevOps API Tasks

## User Story

As a developer, I would like to be able to deploy my docker containers onto ACI.
As a developer, I would like to be able to comment on a PR in Azure DevOps.

## Problem
While we have support for Azure Web Apps, Service Fabric, and AKS, we don't yet have good support for ACI. Additionally (surprisingly), we have even less support for interacting with Azure DevOps via PR comments, issues, etc.

## Use Case
It would be absolutely fantastic if I as a developer could achieve the following from a high level:

1. Build My App
2. Run My Tests
3. Generate a Docker Container
4. Push the container to a registry
5. Generate a "preview" release on ACI
6. Comment a link on the PR indicating where I can see my preview on ACI
7. Once a PR is merged, terminate the preview in ACI.
  * Or once a new build occurs, terminate the old preview, and spin up a new one.

Currently, 1-4 of this are readily available via DevOps tasks. 5-7 are absolutely possible but require creating custom tasks or difficult to maintain scripts.

With the recent announcement of Zeit's "Now" platform [no longer planning on supporting docker containers](https://spectrum.chat/?t=96985341-e17f-4af4-a330-c726774ed436), this seems like a good time to approach the above concepts as the technology in Azure Pipelines/Azure is 95% there, but needs that extra little nudge over the edge.

data.title: DotNetCoreCLI commands are inconsistent
data.body:
The DotNETCoreCLI task supports various commands however they all seem to be inconsistent. A couple examples:

`arguments`: While the task supports an optional arguments parameter it doesn't get used by all the tasks. I was trying to pass additional augments to the pack command and while the YAML accepts it the pack command completely ignores it. 

Another example is the verbosity parameter some if you check out the documentation you see "verbosity" listed twice in the doc table and in the same command you see it listed at `verbosityRestore` and `verbosityPack`. Is there really any reason that all the commands cannot simply use `verbosity` as it is a common option for all.

Please work on cleaning up this task to make the different commands consistent and only add additional parameters for things that are truly unique for the given command. At this point to workaround these I will need to stop using the DotNETCoreCLI task and make the call directly with a script.

data.title: Warning into builds pipelines: Use Cipheriv for counter mode of aes-256-ctr
data.body:
## Issue Description
_Tasks: Install an Apple provisioning profile, Xcode, PowerShell, Command Line, Shell Script ..._

We faced next warning into builds pipelines: 
> Warning: Use Cipheriv for counter mode of aes-256-ctr

Looks like here is **fix** for this: https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/16746#issuecomment-341900420

Also its discussed on the **forum**: https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/475022/getting-warning-use-cipheriv-on-various-stages-of.html

Is this known issue? Do you plan to fix it?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40772628/54126543-d978fe80-4418-11e9-85e7-87021830b8a6.png)


## Environment

Agent - Hosted on MacOS

data.title: Azure Resource Group deployment task should allow overriding a secret having reference to keyVault
data.body:
Currently the task does not allow overriding a parameter which is a reference type. It should be possible to override it with a JSON string containing reference object.

See attached thread for more details. It specified a workaround, but that requires user to create nested templates.
[RE_ Azure Pipeline _ ARM Deployment w_KeyVault .zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/2945414/RE_.Azure.Pipeline._.ARM.Deployment.w_KeyVault.zip)

data.title: Conditionally update build number with PowerShell in container job
data.body:
## Environment
**Software:** Azure Pipelines
**Pool VM Image:** ubuntu-16.04
**Container:** mcr.microsoft.com/powershell

## Issue Description

When running a container job and executing a PowerShell task, if the build number is conditionally set in PowerShell it will fail. I can reproduce this with this definition.

```
name: 0.0.0-a

pool:
  vmImage: 'ubuntu-16.04'

container:
  image: mcr.microsoft.com/powershell

steps:
- powershell: |
    if ($true) {
      Write-Output "##vso[build.updatebuildnumber]0.0.1-b"
    } else {
      Write-Output "##vso[build.updatebuildnumber]0.0.1-c"
    }
```

This problem also occurs if you use a PowerShell variable for the build number. It does not occur when running an agent job (instead of container job).

### Task logs

Please let me know if required.


### Error logs

```

data.title: NPM Publish Allow specifying tags or lack of for latest
data.body:
Currently anything getting published to an private internal feed will get the "latest" tag creating a problem when allowing for prerelease and release versions.

My current setup has an internal feed which local repos publish to, and a second feed with an upstream to the internal feed and to npmjs, if I use the upstream internal@local then latest will usually be a prerelease, internal@release and I can't install prerelease, using both internal@prerelease and internal@release then I have to specify exact versions to avoid prerelease versions.

I think this would be solved by allowing us to set the tag/s on the task.

data.title: [Feature Request] Task to invoke vcvarsall and persist the changes
data.body:
In brief: I think there should be a task which is equivalent to calling `vcvarsall.bat my_args` and making it so that the changes are persisted to subsequent tasks (e.g., the [CMake task](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/build/cmake?view=azure-devops)).

This would make it a lot easier to use, e.g., `clang-cl` as the compiler on the hosted Windows image while still using the CMake task.

I spent quite a lot of time trying to sort this out the other day. Note for example some other `azure-pipelines.yml` files resort to invoking CMake manually, calling `vcvarsXXX.bat` before every single one:
https://github.com/psi4/psi4/blob/7110c8f6399ab40936d9b1f6c18b5ecc3105c4e4/azure-pipelines.yml#L65

https://github.com/kfrlib/kfr/blob/55ec09e9c072a63735fd617953cb36826d4bdace/azure-pipelines.yml#L91

I have come up with a hacky implementation of the suggested task, tailored to my very specific use case of building with clang-cl on Windows images:
https://dev.azure.com/ossiaco/ossiaco/_git/AzureTemplates?path=%2Fclang-cl-setup.yml&version=GBmaster&line=33&lineStyle=plain&lineEnd=59&lineStartColumn=2&lineEndColumn=48

Unfortunately there are some weird hoops to jump through to make sure the original PATH is appended to rather than clobbered

You can see it in use, e.g., here:
https://dev.azure.com/ossiaco/ossiaco/_git/JsonConverter?path=%2Fazure-pipelines.yml&version=GBmaster&line=33&lineStyle=plain&lineEnd=72&lineStartColumn=1&lineEndColumn=1

Note that I specify `lld-link` as the linker due to another weird quirk where the existing condition of the PATH variable makes it so that `Git/bin/link.exe` is otherwise discovered first. However, happily I am able to use my CMake task templates which use the CMake task to invoke configure/generate and build.

I'll mention this issue https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-image-generation/issues/270#issuecomment-469768097 which would partially obviate the need for this one, making it possible to use `clang-cl` with the default Visual Studio CMake generator. However I think the task I've described above could still be useful (or required) if one wanted to use Ninja.

data.title: PackerBuildV1: Custom Managed Image azure template fails validation
data.body:
## Environment Azure Pipelines. Agent: Hosted VS2017 ## Issue Description Attempting to use PackerBuildV1 with a Custom Managed Image fails to validate the azure templates. This looks like the functionality for Custom Managed Images did not get setup in the task PR. The included packer templates attempted to use the unmanaged VHD input process to then output a Managed Image which is not supported in packer. Additionally it is not possible to use the Advanced -> Additional Builder parameters to insert the correct values as the template still references the unmanaged VHD configuration and the Task does not include the proper code to support Custom Managed Images for Azure Templates. It may be possible to use a from scratch packer template to process the Custom Managed Image but this has not yet been tested. ### Task logs

data.title: Please add Pull Request Number into Release Pipeline variables
data.body:
## Environment
- Azure Pipelines
- Agent: Hosted VS 2017

## Issue Description

With the new release to VS for the [Pull Request Release Pipeline](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/release/deploy-pull-request-builds?view=azure-devops), it would be useful to include the Pull Request Number as an environment variable, similar to [System.PullRequest.PullRequestNumber](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/build/variables?view=azure-devops#system-variables) in the Build Pipeline.

data.title: PackerBuild should have a built-in option for uploading the build using Azure storage
data.body: Copying the build artifact using Packer would use WinRM for windows - which is known to be slow. We can give an option in the task to use Azure Storage as a temporary placeholder.

data.body:
## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Private
    - Windows Server 2016 x64 with Agent 2.144.2

## Issue Description

The task DeleteFilesV1 doesn't find files or folders starting with a dot with its patterns. This differs from CopyFilesV2, which does copy files/folders starting with a dot. So if you use the same pattern in both a copy and a delete task, not all copied files will be deleted.

The problem is here: https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/DeleteFilesV1/deletefiles.ts#L59-L65
Custom `matchOptions` are passed, but `dot: true` is not set.
Compare to https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-task-lib/blob/master/node/task.ts#L1413-L1426 where this and many other options are set by default, but not used for DeleteFilesV1 because custom options are passed.

### Task logs

Nothing interesting here
```

2019-01-30T15:04:12.6952378Z Task         : Delete Files
2019-01-30T15:04:12.6952431Z Description  : Delete files or folders. (The minimatch patterns will only match file paths, not folder paths)
2019-01-30T15:04:12.6952484Z Version      : 1.1.6
2019-01-30T15:04:12.6952552Z Author       : Microsoft Corporation
2019-01-30T15:04:12.6952604Z Help         : [More Information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=722333)
2019-01-30T15:04:12.6952929Z ==============================================================================
2019-01-30T15:04:16.4039069Z ##[section]Finishing: Delete archived source
```

data.body:
```
#azure-pipelines.yml
trigger: none

jobs:
  - job: build_troubleshoot
    pool:
      vmImage: 'vs2017-win2016'
    steps:
    - task: PowerShell@2
      displayName: 'Run Inline PowerShell with Arguments'
      inputs:
        targetType: inline
        arguments: -First the_first_arg -Second the_second_arg
        script: |
            Param ([Parameter(Mandatory)][string]$First, [Parameter(Mandatory)][string]$Second)
            
            Write-Host $First
            Write-Host $Second
```

Using inline mode with arguments results in an error. Packaging the exact script that is used in inline mode into a file and using targetType: filepath works. My theory is the parser or script generator is causing the script to shift down a line and with the `Param` statement on the second line and not the first, the script fails.

This is easily reproducible by using the YAML excerpt provided above. Is this desired behavior or a bug... I can't find any documentation stating that inline targetType PowerShellV2 tasks don't support using arguments.

data.title: Add V3 version of JenkinsQueueJob task
data.body:
The JenkinsQueueJobV2 task is using an older vsts-task-lib version and the requests library. This change introduces a V3 version of the task that takes in a newer task-lib version and the typed-rest-client. The newly added webclient class provides a wrapper around the typed-rest-client library allowing for us to customize the retry logic for calls to Jenkins and additional error logging.

The util class still needs to be updated to use the new webclient. The logic that submits jobs to Jenkins will require additional work in order to port it over to the webclient. All other classes have been updated.

Additionally this task needs to be updated to use async-await. This will be done in a separate PR.

Tested in a local deployment that mirrors BuildCanary.
Updated and ran L0 tests.

data.title: Searching a way to allow specific matrix entries to fail
data.body:
## Environment
Repo: [diesel.rs/diesel](https://github.com/diesel-rs/diesel/)

## Issue Description

We have setup azure pipelines as automatic CI service for diesel.rs. That works mostly fine.
Now it is specific to the rust ecosystem that there are several compiler version, notably a stable version, a beta version and a nightly version. The later is updated every night a may not work. To detect such broken version projects are encouraged to run their CI also with the nightly version of the rust compiler, but setup the CI in such a way that failing builds with a nightly compiler are ignored. Basically I've found no way to do this with azure pipelines.

data.title: Feature request: allow specifying files to exclude in ArchiveFiles task
data.body:
## Feature Request

Currently, ArchiveFiles adds every file in a given directory to the created zip file. It would be nice to be able to specify particular files/folders to not publish even if present, e.g. ".git". This can be worked around by adding a script that moves unwanted files outside the directory before running the ArchiveFiles task, but it would be nicer to be able to do this as part of the task itself.

data.title: Add an Upload Secure File task
data.body:
As a VSTS user, it would be immensely helpful to be able to upload/update secure files from a build task. For example, LetsEncrypt certs that expire every 90 days. The renewal task could be automated and moved to a build task to eliminate the need for specific hardware running that job outside of control. 

In the meantime, is there an API endpoint for managing secure files?

data.title: MSBuild task does not recognize VS2019
data.body:
At first glance, this issue seems to be partly in:

1.  Select-MSBuildPath (located in Tasks\Common\MSBuildHelpers\PathFunctions.ps1), which has a hardcoded list of versions that goes up to 15.0
```
$versions = '15.0', '14.0', '12.0', '4.0' | Where-Object { $_ -ne $PreferredVersion }
```
2. Get-MSBuildPath which only does the vswhere.exe query when $version is 15.0 (also in Tasks\Common\MSBuildHelpers\PathFunctions.ps1)
```
        if (($Version -eq "15.0" -or !$Version) -and # !$Version indicates "latest"
            ($visualStudio15 = Get-VisualStudio_15_0) -and
            $visualStudio15.installationPath) {

            $msbuildUtilitiesPath = [System.IO.Path]::Combine($visualStudio15.installationPath, "MSBuild\15.0\Bin\Microsoft.Build.Utilities.Core.dll")
            if (Test-Path -LiteralPath $msbuildUtilitiesPath -PathType Leaf) {
                Write-Verbose "Loading $msbuildUtilitiesPath"
                $msUtilities = [System.Reflection.Assembly]::LoadFrom($msbuildUtilitiesPath)
            }
        }

        # Fallback to searching the GAC.
        # ...
```
3. Get-VisualStudio_15_0, which is fine by itself but probably needs to be refactored to handle 16.0 (similar to the change made to detect VS2019 for agent capabilities in https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-agent/pull/2005)

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 


- Agent: Private: 
    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 
**Agent is running Win2012R2 and the agent version is 2.144.1.**

## Issue Description

When using the MSBuild task on an agent which has VS2019 installed, the agent does not detect that instance of VS and will fallback to an earlier MSBuild agent.

In the log below, it fails to find the instance for VS 2019 (16.0), and falls back to MSBuild v4.0 as ships with .NET framework (the build then fails because of the /bl flag, which was introduced to MSBuild in 15.3).

data.title: Improving CMake Task
data.body:
## Environment
TFS on premise. Version 15.117.27024.0

## Issue Description

The current CMake Task is basically worthless. All the benefits to the "Command Line" Task is adding cmake as executable and setting the demand.

## Proposed enhancements

* If Demand CMAKE points to cmake.exe, use this cmake.exe
* Support and Demand multiple different cmake versions that can be installed in parallel
* Add variables
* Verbose option
* Build Mode (Release, Debug, ... + free form)
* Additional command line parameters
* Drop down box: "Configure", "Build", "Install", "Run Script", "Test"
* On Configure set source and configuration directory (maybe save configuration directory to variable for following CMake Build etc. tasks), Set Generator (add demands acordingly), Set Toolset (add demands acordingly)
* On Install: Install directory (CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX), Component
* On Test: Component, Regex for test, Make Badge with results, add results to Build Overview

## Environment
- Server: **Azure Pipelines**
- Agent: **Hosted** , `Hosted Ubuntu 1604`

## Issue Description

I've got NuGet `push` task looking like this:

```yaml
- task: NuGetCommand@2
  displayName: 'NuGet | PUSH [DEV]'
  inputs:
    command: push
    packagesToPush: '!$(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory)/*.Release.$(GitVersion.NugetVersion).nupkg;$(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory)/*.$(GitVersion.NugetVersion).nupkg'
    publishVstsFeed: 'MyFeed'
    verbosityPush: 'Detailed'
```

The `$(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory)` contents are similar to this:

```
MyPackage.Release.0.459.0-stable4862.nupkg
MyPackage.0.459.0-stable4862.nupkg
```

File pattern is supposed to exclude package with `.Release.0.459.0-stable4862.nupkg` and push only `MyPackage.0.459.0-stable4862.nupkg`.

Hi,

It is now possible to use ARM to deploy directly to Subscriptions, for example to create a [Resource Group](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/create-resource-group-in-template) or for [Azure Policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/deploy-to-subscription). data.title: Why the variable "SourceBranchName" is overwritten to "merge" in case of PullRequest builds?
data.body:
## Environment
- TFS on-premises: 16.131.27701.1
- Agent - Private: Windows, Agent 2.131

## Issue Description
We have a build definition for the master branch with the following "Build number format" configuration:
$(BuildDefinitionName)_$(SourceBranchName)_$(date:yyyyMMdd)$(rev:.r)

When creating a Pull Request to merge into master, this build definition is used to build the sources on feature branch. In this case the variable SourceBranchName is not (anymore) the real branch name, but simply "merge".
Why?

I think this issue is close to #2147 but maybe with slightly different focus. This is why I created a new one.

I would like to see any variable usable in the "Build number format" configuration providing the "feature branch" name in a "Build number format" compatible format. Even more I would like to see the "source branch" in "SourceBranchName"...

The variable SYSTEM_PULLREQUEST_SOURCEBRANCH - mentioned in #2147 - provides value like "refs/heads/FeatureABC", but I would like to see simply "FeatureABC".

Currently I'm using a PS script overwriting the build number while executing (##vso[build.updatebuildnumber]). This is not a final solution because the revision numbering is not correct:
1. The first PR build is named e.g. "MyTool_merge_20181101.1".
2. Due to PS script the build will be renamed to "MyTool_merge_FeatureABC_20181101.1". (Ok so far.)
3. The second PR build is named again "MyTool_merge_20181101.1", because (I assume) the revision numbering is based on original number format pattern.
4. So the second build will be renamed to "MyTool_merge_FeatureABC_20181101.1" and will overwrite the previous build.

data.title: Windows Machine File Copy task to skip default options
data.body:
## Problem statement and request:

Please provide a way (e.g. in UI: checkbox, and in YAML: property) to opt out of default options, in particular `/S` and `/E` options, from robocopy command in `Windows Machine File Copy` TFS task.

When we specify `Files` filter, in addition to copying those files, it creates the whole directory/subdirectories structure (mostly empty due to file filter). There is no way to avoid creation of directories.

## Some background and details

Consider the following options used by `Windows Machine File Copy` task in TFS:

By default, it copies all files, and the log message shows:

```
Files: *.*
Options: *.* /S /E /DCOPY:DA /COPY:DAT /R:1000000 /W:30
```

If we specify Files:

```
Files: File1.txt
    File2.txt
Options: /S /E /DCOPY:DA /COPY:DAT /R:1000000 /W:30
```

with `Clean Target` and `Copy Files in Parallel` checkboxes checked:

```
Options: /S /E /DCOPY:DA /COPY:DAT /PURGE /MIR /R:1000000 /W:30
```

According to help:

```cmd
robocopy /?

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   ROBOCOPY     ::     Robust File Copy for Windows
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Started : Friday, October 19, 2018 11:32:22 AM
              Usage :: ROBOCOPY source destination [file [file]...] [options]

             source :: Source Directory (drive:\path or \\server\share\path).
        destination :: Destination Dir  (drive:\path or \\server\share\path).
               file :: File(s) to copy  (names/wildcards: default is "*.*").

::
:: Copy options :
::
                 /S :: copy Subdirectories, but not empty ones.
                 /E :: copy subdirectories, including Empty ones.

  /COPY:copyflag[s] :: what to COPY for files (default is /COPY:DAT).
                       (copyflags : D=Data, A=Attributes, T=Timestamps).
                       (S=Security=NTFS ACLs, O=Owner info, U=aUditing info).

             /PURGE :: delete dest files/dirs that no longer exist in source.
               /MIR :: MIRror a directory tree (equivalent to /E plus /PURGE).

 /DCOPY:copyflag[s] :: what to COPY for directories (default is /DCOPY:DA).
                       (copyflags : D=Data, A=Attributes, T=Timestamps).

::
:: File Selection Options :
::
...
...

::
:: Retry Options :
::
               /R:n :: number of Retries on failed copies: default 1 million.
               /W:n :: Wait time between retries: default is 30 seconds.
...
...

::
:: Logging Options :
::
...
...

::
:: Job Options :
::

...
...
```

In order to skip copying directory structure (aka: omit `/S` and `/E`) when the intent is to *only* copy bunch of files, is currently not possible.

data.title: npm task fails to authenticate (works when using command line task instead)

## Environment

## Issue Description

We have a private Artifactory instance. The agent service account's profile has an .npmrc file with a valid authentication token. When I log in as that account and run npm install from command line, it works. When I create a command task in the build and run it, it works. When I use the npm task, it fails. In short, something is wrong with the npm task's ability to authenticate. This isn't a failure of npm.
